data.title: Vector based SDF
data.body:
First of all, I do not want to remove the current font system (I will get to that later). However, with all new fancy stuff like Virtual Reality headsets and 4K monitors etc. I was thinking that one problem encountered is the display quality of text. Then I remembered a project that I found 2 years ago, GLyphy: https://github.com/behdad/glyphy

See this video if you want to know more about how GLyphy works:
http://vimeo.com/behdad/glyphy

Most other projects sample the SDF into a texture. This has all the usual problems that sampling has. Ie. it distorts the outline and is low quality. GLyphy instead represents the SDF using actual vectors submitted to the GPU. This results in very high quality rendering, though at a much higher runtime cost.

I do not see why godot should remove the bitmap based font system (it has less runtime costs and works well) but a vector based SDF (GLyphy) could complement this for projects that need better display quality of text.

data.title: Various fixes for TabContainer. also Fix issue #7752 ... v3
data.body:
- Renamed `tab_changed` signal to `tab_selected`. Which still emits a signal by reselecting the active tab.
- Added `tab_changed` signal. Which emits a signal if and only if previous tab does not equal current tab.
- Added `get_previous_tab()`. Which returns the previous shown tab. **Note:** only `tab_changed` can modify previous tab index.
- Add documentation for the added function and signals. Fix a typo too.

data.title: GraphNode doesn't handle expand flag
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

All

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Linux, current master

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

GraphNode doesn't take the expand flag of it's children (SIZE_EXPAND) into account.
Instead, it behaves as if horizontal expand is enabled and vertical fill is disabled for children.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Add any UI component under GraphNode and turn on expand flags.


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->:

data.title: Spinbox: don't ignore double clicks.
data.body:
Fixes the problem with spinboxes not updating when clicking too fast.
Fixes #7800

data.title: Use real_t as floating point type in physics code.
data.body: This is a continuation of an on-going work for 64-bit floating point builds, started in PR #7528. Covers physics, physics/joints and physics_2d code.

data.title: Remove bounds check when resuming from yield. (fixes #7796)
data.body:
The code would get a pointer to the beginning of the call_args by using
operator[] at the stack Vector. This does bound checking. When there are
no call_args this bound check fails and the error mentioned in #7796
gets triggered.

This bound check is actually not necessary as call_args just gets set to
NULL and never dereferenced. This new code will just unconditionally set
the pointer to the place where the call_args are if there are any. There
is no NULL check for call_args anywhere so this is safe.

data.title: Spinbox: arrow buttons are not always responding
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
master, Linux 64bit (but should be platform-independent)

**Issue description:**
As noted in #7790, the little spinbox buttons are not responding to every click.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Add a spinbox and click the increment or decrement button a few times, sometimes it won't change the value.

data.title: Godot 3.0 KinematicBody2D with CollisionShape2D reports no collisions against StaticBody2D with CollisionShape2D
data.body:
I dont know if in the refactoring of Godot 3.0 collisions are still a WIP, if this is the case, please ignore this

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 Home 64bits
Godot 3.0
VS 2013

**Issue description:**
a simple KinematicBody2D with any CollisionShape2D and a gravity applied to it on its func _process(delta): goes right trough a StaticBody2D with a CollisionShape2D without reporting "is_colliding"


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. create a KinematicBody2D
2. add a CollisionShape2D  (a rectangle of 10x10 would do) as a child of the KinematicBody2D
3. create a StaticBody2D and place it bellow the KinematicBody2D (500px would do)
4. add a CollisionShape2D  (a rectangle of 100x10 would do) as a child of the StaticBody2D 
5. add some gravity in the _process(delta) E.g.:

```
var speed_y = 0
func _ready():
 set_process(true)

func _process(delta):
  speed_y += 100 * delta
  move(Vector2(0,speed_y))
  if is_colliding():
    print("collision")
  pass
```
(_Bugsquad edit: fixed formatting_)

data.title: Fix for issue #7766
data.body:
When calling get_mouse_mode() on OS_OSX, garbage was returned.  This is because mouse_mode was not initialized in the constructor for OS_OSX.

Add initialization for OS_OSX.mouse_mode in OS_OSX::OS_OSX().  mouse_mode now defaults to OS::MOUSE_MODE_VISIBLE.

_Bugsquad edit:_ fixes #7766

data.title: GDScript vector.h error with yield
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.x, probably 3.x too

**Issue description:**
_(Issue found in collaboration with user Zhelvad on discord)_
Doing something except `print` or a call to something of the base class after `yield` leads to a `vector.h` error:
```
ERROR: operator[]: Condition ' p_index<0 || p_index>=size() ' is true. returned: aux
   At: core/vector.h:132.
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
Run this script on some node:

```gdscript
extends Control # For the set call

signal test()

var wait_function_frames = 10
var wait_signal_frames = 20

func _ready():
	assert(wait_function_frames < wait_signal_frames)
	set_process(true)

func _process(delta):
	wait_function_frames -= 1
	if wait_function_frames == 0:
		do_stuff()
	
	wait_signal_frames -= 1
	if wait_signal_frames == 0:
		set_process(false)
		emit_signal("test") # Error reported here, but actually below (non-issue)

func do_stuff():
	yield(self, "test") # Throws error
	
	# Any of the following 4 lead to no thrown error if uncommented
	#print(4)
	#set("position", Vector2(1,1))
	#get("position")
	# return print(4)
	
	# All of the next 5 lines don't change the error reported (comment any of them if you want to)
	do_nothing()
	do_something()
	max(5,4)
	pass
	return 1

func do_nothing(): pass

func do_something(): set("position", Vector2(2,2))
```

**Link to minimal example project:**
Script above + a scene is easy to prepare on your own, but, still...
[zhelvad-yield.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/771285/zhelvad-yield.zip)

```
<reduz> ok
```

data.title: Fix compile error with TextureButton
data.body:
Export TextureButton::ResizeMode as its own enum values

Tested on Arch Linux with GCC 6.3.1

data.title: "Collision Groups" handling Collision Layers & Masks
data.body:
This is an ongoing idea that I am building on, and I believe this have the potential to simplify collision layers and masks - for intermediate and beginners alike. 

While I was working on a tutorial explaining Collision Layers and Masks thoroughly, I realize that a lot of the work consists of having to manage and setting up the individual collision layers and masks.

While I realize we have a "Groups" tab that allows us to set groups, it does not directly affect collision layers and masks without going into gdscript of each object and managing collisions from there. 
You could argue that you could check which group "I am on" and set layers and masks from code - and I am sure that would work, but that is not simple or effective - at least not compared to this possible solution.

For example, when working with layers and masks I usually plan ahead of what types of objects will be in which layers and interact with which masks. This is an example of my note:

**Collision Layers | Masks**
1 - Static Objects (immovable objects, floor, roof, etc.) <-> 2, 3, 4
2 - Friendly Rigid Bodies (crates, player, etc.) <-> 1, 2, 3, 5
3 - Enemy Rigid Bodies <-> 1, 2, 4
4 - Player Bullets  <-> 1, 3
5 - Enemy Bullets <-> 1, 2

I realize that keeping this consistent can be incredibly awkward. Having to go back to my list every time I create new objects. 
After all, for **every**, **single**, **object** I make; I would have to go into the inspector and manually set individual layers and masks.

So this idea hit me; Why not create a "Collision Group" system, that allows us to setup individual collision groups for those masks and layers? 

Imagine having an simple drop down menu in place of Collision Layers and Masks that allows you to set a new Group or choose an existing group. 
When creating a new group, you set a name for it and select which layer it is on and what it with collide with (masks). 
**Some of the best advantages with this,** is that if you later decide that all static objects should also collide with objects on layer 6, you just edit the group instead of doing inside every single object and manually adding 6 to them.

Group name: "Static Objects" <---- This is what you set on new objects that are static
Layer: 1
Mask: 2,3,4

Group name: "Friendly Rigid Bodies" <---- Easy setup of friendly rigidbodies such as player, crates, etc.
Layer: 2
Mask: 1,2,3,5

_Lastly I should add_; you should not be forced to setup a group - you should still be able to just directly set layers and masks without defining a group.

Thoughts? Feelings? Any flaws that I have not foreseen about this? ;)

data.title: ProjectSettings: InputMap dialog fixes
data.body:
Now the selection jumps to the correct action after a new event has been added.
Also sets the default device id for Joypad button events to 0.
Fixes #7790

data.title: Issues in input map dialog
data.body:
Tested in branch 2.2-legacy

- When adding a joystick button to an action, the "device" value is set to 3
- The little buttons on the spinbox don't respond to half of the clicks (it takes more than 3 clicks to set the value down to 0)
- After adding the button, the selected action becomes the first action that contains the button added, instead of the action that was being edited. For example, add a new action "jump", on the jump action add the button "0: PS X [etc]", the selected action becomes "ui_accept" (the first of the default actions that uses button 0)

data.title: Godot 3.0 error on core/os/os.h builds on windows
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 Home 64bits
Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
Error building on godot\core\os/os.h(406)
because 'bool OS::check_feature_support(const String &)': is abstract

C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\INCLUDE\xlocale(341): warning C4530: C++ exception handler used, but unwind semantics are not enabled. Specify /EHsc
platform\windows\godot_win.cpp(128): error C2259: 'OS_Windows': cannot instantiate abstract class
platform\windows\godot_win.cpp(128): note: due to following members:
platform\windows\godot_win.cpp(128): note: 'bool OS::check_feature_support(const String &)': is abstract
D:\GodotEngine\Godot.3.0\godot\core\os/os.h(406): note: see declaration of 'OS::check_feature_support'
scons: *** [platform\windows\godot_win.windows.tools.64.obj] Error 2
scons: building terminated because of errors.


**Steps to reproduce:**
.-download git source of godot from 2017 feb 12, https://github.com/godotengine/godot
.-install VS 2013 or 2015
.-install python 2.7
.-install scons
.-open a developer/tool command prompt
.-run scons on de godot directory (windows appears as platform)
.-run any of the following commands:
scons p=windows vsproj=yes
scons platform=windows -j 8 tools=yes target=release_debug
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\vcvarsall.bat" x86 && C:\Python27\Scripts\scons platform=windows -j 8 tools=yes target=release_debug
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\vcvarsall.bat" amd64 && C:\Python27\Scripts\scons platform=windows -j 8 tools=yes target=release_debug

***The same steps works for Godot 2.1 brach

data.title: Inf and NaN support added to GDScript
data.body: Exposes Inf and NaN so they can be used in scripting.

data.title: Ability to do per-viewport, customizable LoD in 3D
data.body:
As far as I understand, level of detail (LoD) in Godot is currently achieved by using an existing feature named `draw range` in GeometryInstance, and having multiple instances of the same object at different ranges.

This is fine for local objects, but it becomes nasty when it comes to lodding a terrain, or a forest (anything not "local" or numerous).
Heightmaps or voxel geometry for example require to be split in chunks, and splits are bigger or smaller depending on their LoD level. In addition to that, their boundaries have to be recalculated with different geometry everytime the LoD is changing, and this for every viewport in the same World. It's still involves turning meshes on and off, somehow, but relying only on just `draw range` is impossible, it would need some more custom logic.

Advanced lodding techniques involve collapsing vertices gradually, which is also completely different from `draw range`. And in case Godot won't support this natively, there should be room in the API to be able to implement it as a module.

So the proposal here is as the title says: it would be great if 3.0 had the API possibility of having custom lodding that is not only based on a fixed draw range algorithm (could also be related to https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6375 which is about hysteresis)

data.title: Remove use of _SCS
data.body:
This saves typing in most cases, and makes it less likely that
ADD_METHOD and friends accidentally forget it.

This is a step towards fixing #56

data.title: bad highDpi support with plugins
data.body: **Operating system or device - Godot version:** macOS 2.1 **Issue description:** when using plugins highDpi has issues. the UI elements themselves are scaled correctly, but the spacing/layout is the same than in loDpi which results in overlapping. Also icons are loDpi. **Steps to reproduce:** create a project install a plugins (I used the git plugin) set the editor to highDpi open the git panel

data.title: Fix relative cursor data in CAPTURED mouse mode on Windows.
data.body: This PR is a fix for some glitches on the Windows build concerning sampling relative mouse motion. The data would sometimes be inaccurate and give inverted results, a glitch most notable if testing with a first or third-person camera with a locked axis. Using relative mouse data to control the camera, if you push continually on a locked axis, the camera would 'jitter' as a result. I've only tested this otherwise on the Linux build, but as far as I can tell, this problem only seems to appear on Windows. This should make the behaviour consistent with the Linux build now.

data.title: Fix the JSON dict parser
data.body:
The old code would return OK if there were no more tokens after the
opening curly brace. This caused "{" to be parsed as an empty
dictionary.

This fixes #7741

data.title: Refactor GlobalConfig::setup
data.body:
I have tried to make the code around this constructor a bit easier
to follow and with less redundancy. The engine now no longer tried to
go all the way to the root of the filesystem tree when trying to load
packs or configurations.

Furthermore the engine now tries to find packs in all locations it
checks. The following locations are now checked, in this order:

* game path (-path <dir>)
* os-specific resource dir (if supported)
* current working directory (if supported)
* directory of the godot executable

I believe this is what most users would expect, and is as discussed
on the ticket and IRC.

This change fixes #7764

data.title: making RigidBody2D::_integrate_forces editable in code
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1.2, mint

So i was trying to learn c++ in godot by making in it simple top-down car physics, some investigation lead me to finding `_integrate_forces` within RigidBody2D in gdscript, so after diving down in c++ i found something that i am not sure how to workaround.  
It seems that `_integrate_forces` is being called from non virtual function `_direct_state_changed` and is bind as VMETHOD (i assume its virtual), using `BIND_VMETHOD(MethodInfo("_integrate_forces",PropertyInfo(Variant::OBJECT,"state:Physics2DDirectBodyState")));`  
Shouldn't there be a possibility of overriding `_integrate_forces` in c++?   
I think that would be a nice improvement and with some pointers from some more experienced C++ godot devs, i would gladly add that option.  
The simplest solution to that issue is making `_direct_state_changed` virtual and overriding it in child of RigidBody2D but it doesn't seem right.
I also hope that i did not misunderstood guidelines for contributing, since its my first time doing that in godot repo.

data.title: Frustum camera mode for stereoscopic projection
data.body:
This is a resubmit of my PR #7121 but for the Godot 2.1 branch. I know a few people who are currently doing HMD development still in Godot 2 and as i'm about to fix 7121 for Godot 3 I figured submitting this on the 2.1 branch could be appreciated (not to mention I'm still using it for my OpenVR project :))

All this PR does is introduce a new camera mode called FRUSTUM which allows you to set a left/right/top/bottom frustum from which the projection matrix is calculated. It also adds a few methods to the camera object to set the correct values for stereo projection.

The frustum is set at unit depth, not at the near plane, so you can change the near and far plane without having to adjust the frustum. Also the frustum will be adjusted to the aspect ratio of the viewport by Godot itself so do not adjust the top/bottom of the frustum by aspect ratio, instead set up the frustum assuming a square screen. This keeps the camera independent of the viewport it is used with.

You can find a test project here that sets up the stereo camera rendering to a left/right splitscreen such as you would use with an HMD:
https://github.com/BastiaanOlij/StereoCameraTest

data.body:

The frustum is set at unit depth, not at the near plane, so you can change the near and far plane without having to adjust the frustum. Also the frustum will be adjusted to the aspect ratio of the viewport by Godot itself so do not adjust the top/bottom of the frustum by aspect ratio, instead set up the frustum assuming a square screen.
